something called key performance indicators KPIs to measure user insights
I will then discuss event models and how they can help you capture data in a

three things the first is deliver sports
news and schedules so there's a game going on or tournament just and there it'll send you an update either through
email to the app on your web browser or to the app on your smartphone it will

doing with the application all of the developers that we spoke to gave us
inputs into what they do to capture user insights and we collated all of that
into this analytics funnel framework which seems to work really well for a lot of successful applications which
looks like so it starts with acquisition the user insight that you're trying to
gain here is how many users are you getting every day and what is the trend
so is the number of new users growing day by day is that flatlining do you need to do something about it that's the
kind of user inside you game then comes activation now pretty
much every application has one or more key events that users take right at the
start which signifies that they're now active in your app for the sports fans application that I'm going to use as the
example maybe selecting your favorite team is that key action if it's an
e-commerce app maybe adding your first item to the cart could be that active activation event if it's an e-book
application downloading your first book could be that activity feel free to extrapolate to whatever
applications you're building and think of what that action is for your app so once you understand how many users are
installing your app how many are getting activated the next step is to measure engagement so we saw how the sports fans
application has three features we want to understand which of those features are popular with the users how often do
they use each feature all of this determines what their engagement is with the app then you want to look at whether
an engaged user is retentive so do they like those features enough that they're
coming back to your application every day every week every month and finally
you want to look at which of these users will go on to drive revenue for your
application so those are kind of the user insights that most applications will typically
try to gain from analytics but how do we quantify this because we want to scale
this to millions of users so that's where KPI is a key performance indicators come in and each of these
steps in the funnel have their own KPIs I will discuss some of the more popular ones but I'm sure a lot of you use KPIs
that you've known and trusted feel free to match and makes for
acquisition should be fairly obvious you would calculate the number of new users coming in every day but importantly you
want to look at the source of those installs are they coming in organically from the App Store's on mobile devices
for example are they coming in through search engines social media referrals
oh maybe you're doing paid advertising and acquiring users and that's the channel they're coming in through and it's really important to understand
which of these channels drives the most users to your application it pretty much determines where users are discovering
what you built then with activation as
we discussed you identify the key event or action in your app and do a count of
how many users and how often those actions are taking place on a day to day basis for the Sportsman's application as
I discussed you could use the favorite team selection as that key action because that pretty much tells us what
kind of life scores those users would want what kind of news articles they would want are they likely to buy
tickets to the game for those teams so that's the action I'm going to use for
engagement there's a host of standard KPIs that all app developers measure
things like daily active users monthly active users session counts average session time but because we identified
that key action we would want to track the count of that key action as well on a daily basis retention is interesting
there's a lot of debate and argument about what the right KPIs are for retention two of the more popular ones
that we have seen are the end retention and sticky factor let me talk about that
real quick so the end retention is basically you looking at a cohort of
users that have installed the app on a particular day and tracking that go hot over time to see how many of them are
coming back to use your application so to give you an example what's today Tuesday so let's say the sports fans
application was installed last Tuesday I track that cohort of users I check how
many of them came back on Wednesday and I call that D 1 retention now that's a very important metric because typically
what you see is that when users install the app unless your app immediately conveys what it's doing a lot you lose a
lot of those users on the first day so you want to look at that D 1 retention metric really carefully especially if
you're doing paid advertising that pretty much determines your ROI then I
come to this Tuesday and see how many of these users have come back 7 after installing the application these
users have most likely taken that key action which is why they've come back how to seven days they're likely to be
engaged users and then I go on to D 30 a month after the app was installed these
are more or less loyal users it varies by application obviously but these are
users who probably will go on to generate revenue for your application
then there's sticky factor which kind of flips this on its head what you do with
sticky factor is you look at all of the users that have come into your app today and go back historically to see how
often they've used your app in the past a very popular way to measure sticky factor is look at all the users that
have come in today and check how many of them use your app at least once in the preceding month or preceding 30 days
think of it as da you by Mau in a sense so the higher the number the more likely
that users are coming to your app more often so it's a really good measure of retention and then finally there's
revenue these KPIs again should be fairly obvious you track purchase some
spurt is count you also want to track unique purchases and a lot of developers
take that one step further they also track things like churn rate of pairs now if some of your applications have a

decided to build pin point in a way that it takes away all of that worry from you so let me describe what that events
model is and why it's useful events in pin point have child objects called
attributes and metrics let's look at some examples with that sports France
application in mind so things like topic subscriptions topic views purchases
those all come under events there are actual things that are happening in the application attributes are things that I
used to qualify those events now there are the standard attributes like platform and device locale we'll see in
a bit how pin point captures all of that automatically for you without you having to take up that effort but then you as
the developer would want to track attributes like the name of the article that is being viewed or the name of the item that's being purchased so those are
all attributes then there's metrics metrics are things on which you can do
arithmetic operations so here you would track things like the number of pages consumed per article or the time spent
on a particular article in the case of revenue events you would want to track the amount purchased the
discount then what you can do with the metrics is do things like sums averages
min max p90 what-have-you and make use
of that information to take action in your app pinpoint does the same thing for users and devices as well
note that I call users and devices out separately as we discussed it's a
multi-platform app it works on mobile devices web browsers so you want to be able to understand devices separately
from the same user now typically you would identify a user with some kind of
a unique ID maybe it's a user name or an email or a phone number in fact if you
use Amazon kognito which is a fantastic service for doing exactly that kognito
sends all of this information automatically to pin point all you need to do is check a box and the integration
is automatic so it's really a really elegant way to set up your application for user identification then again
there's user attributes what's the most common device that that user is consuming your application from what are
those users favorite teams is the user a new subscriber or are they interested in
live scores you're basically building a profile of what that user is interested in users also have metrics these are
typically lifetime values and you would use these metrics to understand which
tier a user belongs to so let's say there's a particular user that's doing a lot of ticket purchases you would
collate the total sum of tickets purchased or the amount purchased create a tier of users that belongs to that
